city.cs.engine

Class DynamicBody

  • java.lang.Object
    • city.cs.engine.Body
      • city.cs.engine.DynamicBody

  • public class DynamicBody
extends Body
    A dynamic body moves, rotates and collides with other bodies according to the laws of physics. It has finite mass, with a distribution determined by the densities of its constituent shapes.

    The underlying physics engine works best with dynamic objects between 0.1 and 10 metres in size.

      • applyImpulse

        public void applyImpulse(Vec2 impulse,
                Vec2 point)
        Apply an impulse to this body at a specified position in the world. If the position is not the centre of mass it will create a torque, rotating the body.
        Parameters:
        impulse - the impulse in Newton seconds (first component in x-direction, second component in y-direction)
        point - the point at which to apply the impulse (first component is x, second component is y)

      • applyForce

        public void applyForce(Vec2 force)
        Apply a force to this body at its centre of mass. The force will be applied for the duration of the next time step.
        Parameters:
        force - the force in Newtons (first component in x-direction, second component in y-direction)

      • applyForce

        public void applyForce(Vec2 force,
              Vec2 point)
        Apply a force to this body at a specified position in the world. If the position is not the centre of mass it will create a torque, rotating the body. The force will be applied for the duration of the next time step.
        Parameters:
        force - the force in Newtons (first component in x-direction, second component in y-direction)
        point - the point at which to apply the force (first component is x, second component is y)

        Parameters:
        torque - the torque in Newton metres

      • setBullet

        public void setBullet(boolean b)
        Set the value of the bullet attribute on this body. When this attribute is false (the default), collisions between this object and other dynamic bodies are detected only at the moment of each simulation step. This is usually adequate, but sometimes misses collisions that occur between steps, producing a "tunnelling" effect.

        This doesn't happen with collisions between dynamic and static bodies, because the engine uses continuous collision detection in that case: the dynamic body is swept from its old position to its new position, and if a collision occurs in the sweep the body is moved back to the time of impact.

        Setting the bullet attribute to true turns on continuous collision detection between this body and other dynamic bodies, which is considerably more expensive. It is usually only necessary for small, fast-moving objects (like bullets).

        Parameters:
        b - the new value for the bullet attribute

      • isBullet

        public boolean isBullet()
        Get the value of the bullet attribute on this body.
        Returns:
        use continuous collision detection between this body and other dynamic bodies?

      • setFixedRotation

        public void setFixedRotation(boolean b)
        Set the fixed rotation attribute for this body to true. If set to true, the body will not rotate even when subject to torque. Default is false. Once set to true this attribute cannot be unset.
        Parameters:
        b - the new fixed rotation attribute for this body

      • isFixedRotation

        public boolean isFixedRotation()
        Is the orientation of this body fixed?
        Returns:
        the fixed rotation attribute for this body

      • setGravityScale

        public void setGravityScale(float g)
        Set the gravity scale for this body. The gravity scale is used as a multiplier with the global gravity vector when simulating the effect of gravity on bodies. The default gravity scale for a body is 1.0. It is not physically realistic for different bodies to experience different scales of gravity but can be useful in games. Setting gravity scale to 0 results in a body which is unaffected by gravity. Bodies with a negative gravity scale will accelerate upwards.
        Parameters:
        g - the new gravity scale

      • getGravityScale

        public float getGravityScale()
        Get the gravity scale for this body.
        Returns:
        the gravity scale for this body
